item.title: Ticket #1322 (Paged navigation & htaccess generation fails with "exotic" permalinks) updated
item.dc:creator: Joen
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1322 (Paged navigation & htaccess generation fails with "exotic" permalinks) created
item.dc:creator: Joen
item.description:
I'm using the following permalink structure:

/journal/%year%/%monthnum%/%postname%

In /, I show excerpts, in /journal/ I have WP installed, and show the main blog stuff. My "Blog Address" is /.

When I use the "Next" / "Previous" Posts feature in /journal/, the resulting /journal/page/2/ shows a 404.

This is due to the htaccess expecting paged navigation only on the blog address, with the following rule.

RewriteRule page/?([0-9]{1,})/?$ /index.php?&paged=$1 [QSA,L]

A quick, manual edit fixes it:

RewriteRule journal/page/?([0-9]{1,})/?$ /journal/index.php?&paged=$1 [QSA,L]

I've had not had major problems with other aspects of rewriting, with these "exotic" URIs, so I have to ask: Is the above intentional? Or is it simply impossible to use paged navigation with different blog / WP URIs?

Proposed solution: If possible, allow Paged navigation in both blog URI and wp URI, "just to be sure".

In other words, just write both RewriteRule page/?([0-9]{1,})/?$ /index.php?&paged=$1 [QSA,L] and RewriteRule journal/page/?([0-9]{1,})/?$ /journal/index.php?&paged=$1 [QSA,L] with auto generation.

item.title: Ticket #1306 (Dict lookup regex too restrictive) updated
item.dc:creator: h3h
item.description:
[\w ] was too restrictive, as it won't allow hyphenated words or words with apostrophes (and whatever else you can think up). I do think it's reasonable, however, to require the first character of the word typed to be in \w.

After application of this latest patch you can mark this issue resolved, Matt. Thanks.

item.title: Ticket #1321 (Editing approved posts deletes them) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1321 (Editing approved posts deletes them) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: When any of my author/users (level 1) edits a post I have approved and published, the post disappears. I can no longer see it logged in as admin, or as the user, though it appears in edit listings ... when I click it, WP says "post not found." This is reproducible every time. Help!

item.title: Ticket #1310 (RSS enclosures) updated
item.dc:creator: matt
item.description:
WordPress supports multiple enclosures (if users choose) per post just like email programs support more than one attachment per email. I'm sure some people will only ever enclose one thing at a time, and that's fine. It's not up to the software to restrict people based on a loose interpretation of intention, especially when the intention in future versions of RSS was clearer:

â€‹http://backend.userland.com/rss093#changes

item.title: Ticket #1316 (WP should block Google's Web Accelerator in wp-admin) updated
item.dc:creator: matt
item.description:
Index: C:/Documents and Settings/Matt/Desktop/WordPress/wp-admin/admin-functions.php =================================================================== --- C:/Documents and Settings/Matt/Desktop/WordPress/wp-admin/admin-functions.php (revision 2587) +++ C:/Documents and Settings/Matt/Desktop/WordPress/wp-admin/admin-functions.php (working copy) @@ -466,11 +466,13 @@

}

function check_admin_referer() {

  • $adminurl = strtolower(get_settings('siteurl')).'/wp-admin';
  • $referer = strtolower($_SERVERHTTP_REFERER?);
  • if ( !strstr($referer, $adminurl) ) {
  • die(('Sorry, you need to <a href="â€‹http://codex.wordpress.org/Enable_Sending_Referrers">enable sending referrers</a> for this feature to work.'));
  • }

+ $adminurl = strtolower(get_settings('siteurl')).'/wp-admin'; + $referer = strtolower($_SERVERHTTP_REFERER?); + if ( !strstr($referer, $adminurl) ) { + die(('Sorry, you need to <a href="â€‹http://codex.wordpress.org/Enable_Sending_Referrers">enable sending referrers</a> for this feature to work.')); + } + if ( isset( $_SERVERHTTP_X_MOZ? ) && $_SERVERHTTP_X_MOZ? == 'prefetch' ) + die();

}

item.title: Ticket #1320 (wp_list_pages gives invalid XTHML) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1320 (wp_list_pages gives invalid XTHML) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
I've been getting invalid XHTML reports on my blog, which has resulted from using two lists of pages which have the same list item ID 'pagenav'. The bug is in the function wp_list_pages (wp-includes/template-functions-post.php):

if ( $rtitle_li? )

echo '<li id="pagenav">' . $rtitle_li? . '<ul>';

The validator reports that having two list items with the same ID is invalid XHTML. Perhaps a class should be used here rather than an ID?

item.title: Ticket #1319 (Category RSS feed function broken) updated
item.dc:creator: baptiste
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1319 (Category RSS feed function broken) created
item.dc:creator: baptiste
item.description:
If you call list_cats in a template sidebar, for example, with an RSS graphic included for $feed_iamge in the parameters so you can display RSS feed links for each category, the links returned for the RSS image are â€‹http://yoursite.com/category/feed/ over and over. The category is never listed in the RSS link.

In feed-functions.php, function get_category_rss_link is using $category_id instead of the passed $cat_ID on lines 113 and 115. Replace $category with $cat_ID and the links are properly generated.

In /wordpress/wp-admin/templates.php, line 140 should be changed from

<p><?php _e('To edit a file, type its name here. You can edit any file <a href="â€‹http://wiki.wordpress.org/index.php/MakeWritable" title="Read more about making files writable">writable by the server</a>, e.g. CHMOD 666.') ?></p>

to

<p><?php _e('To edit a file, type its name here. You can edit any file <a href="â€‹http://codex.wordpress.org/Changing_File_Permissions" title="Read more about making files writable">writable by the server</a>, e.g. CHMOD 666.') ?></p>

item.title: Ticket #1181 (comment posting leads to blank page) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis de Bernardy
item.description:
Could it be that the WP spam fighting procedures are causing the problem? If your session times out for any reason, you would be considered a 'new session' that starts with a 'post new comment' page rather than 'display a post' page for you to comment immediately after. Posting a comment directly would be a typical bot behavior...

The full details of another user who encountered a problem: Mac with MacOS 10.3.9, FireFox 1.0.3, cable modem with Comcast, default preferences, no connection problems while he was commenting. The same user can leave comments on his WP install, so it may be a timeout problem or something like that. Any thoughts?

item.title: Ticket #1316 (WP should block Google's Web Accelerator in wp-admin) updated
item.dc:creator: michel v
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1316 (WP should block Google's Web Accelerator in wp-admin) created
item.dc:creator: michel v
item.description: Due to the presence of non-idempotent links like Delete in Manage Posts, or +/- promote links in Users, WordPress should filter out GWA requests from wp-admin/.
